Table 1: Number of communication rounds and stochastic gradients per client to reach ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon-stationary point (‖∇Φ‖≤ϵnorm∇Φitalic-ϵ\|\nabla\Phi\|\leq\epsilon) for federated non-convex-PL min-max learning, denoted as communication and client sample complexity.
We omit the higher orders.
Here m𝑚m is the number of clients.
BGD means bounded gradient dissimilarity, which requires bounded data heterogeneity.
𝖲𝖠𝖦𝖣𝖠𝖲𝖠𝖦𝖣𝖠\mathsf{SAGDA}~{}supports client sampling and does not require BGD assumption.

references:
Corollary 1 says that, for sufficiently many communication rounds (T=Ω​(m​K)𝑇Ω𝑚𝐾T=\Omega(mK)), 𝖲𝖠𝖦𝖣𝖠𝖲𝖠𝖦𝖣𝖠\mathsf{SAGDA}~{}achieves the linear speedup in both m𝑚m and K𝐾K.
In other words, the per-client sample complexity and communication complexity are 𝒪​((1/m)​ϵ−4)𝒪1𝑚superscriptitalic-ϵ4\mathcal{O}((1/m)\epsilon^{-4}) and 𝒪​(ϵ−2)𝒪superscriptitalic-ϵ2\mathcal{O}(\epsilon^{-2}), respectively.
The per-client sample complexity indicates the benefits of parallelism as the number of clients m𝑚m increases.
The communication complexity significantly improves those in existing works by at least a (1/ϵ)1italic-ϵ(1/\epsilon)-factor (cf. Table 1).
